message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting symptoms of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD), with irritability and cravings for sweet foods. Fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, is the most appropriate treatment for PMDD. Cognitive behavioral therapy may be helpful but not as the primary treatment. Avoidance of nicotine may be a good general recommendation for health but is not directly related to the patient's symptoms. Naproxen is not specifically indicated for PMDD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest premenstrual dysmorphic disorder (PMDD), which is treated with SSRIs such as fluoxetine. Cognitive behavioral therapy may also be helpful, but pharmacotherapy is the first-line treatment. Nicotine is not directly related to PMDD symptoms, and naproxen is used to treat menstrual cramps, which are not the patient’s main complaint.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is likely experiencing premenstrual syndrome with symptoms including headaches, difficulty sleeping, decreased concentration, angry feelings, and cravings for sweets. Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor commonly used to treat premenstrual dysphoric disorder. Cognitive behavioral therapy and avoidance of nicotine may be helpful, but they are not the first-line treatment for premenstrual dysphoric disorder. Naproxen may help relieve physical symptoms but it is not effective for mood symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD), which is a severe form of premenstrual syndrome (PMS). Fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, is the first-line treatment for PMDD. Cognitive behavioral therapy and avoidance of nicotine may help but are not specific for PMDD. Naproxen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, may help with physical symptoms but not emotional symptoms.

The patient’s symptoms suggest premenstrual syndrome (PMS) which can be treated with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as fluoxetine. Cognitive behavioral therapy may be helpful, but pharmacologic treatment is usually recommended first. Nicotine avoidance may be beneficial for other health reasons, but it is not specifically indicated for PMS. Naproxen may help with physical symptoms such as cramps but may not address the emotional symptoms described by the patient.

Cognitive behavioral therapy and avoidance of nicotine may have some benefits, but they are not the first-line treatment for PMS. Naproxen can help with physical symptoms of PMS but it is not effective in treating the psychological symptoms.

The patient's symptoms suggest premenstrual syndrome (PMS), which is characterized by emotional and physical symptoms that occur during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle. Fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), has been shown to be effective in treating PMS symptoms. Cognitive behavioral therapy can also be helpful, but medication is likely indicated in this case. Avoidance of nicotine may be recommended for other health reasons but is not directly related to the PMS symptoms. Naproxen may be helpful for physical symptoms such as cramping, but is less effective for emotional symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder (PMDD), characterized by mood changes, irritability, and cravings for sweet foods. Among the options, only Fluoxetine, a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI), is approved for the treatment of PMDD. Cognitive behavioral therapy may help, but medication is the first-line treatment. Avoidance of nicotine and naproxen are not specific treatments for PMDD.
